Description: Body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery lekane with out-turned rim; white slip; interior: from top, painted decoration consisting of undetermined motif; below, key maeander frieze running left between dilute lines; below, part of elaborate floral pattern to left of a goat (head, neck and part of shoulder remaining) to left; trace of pendant triangle, pendant roundel and elaborate rosettes as filling ornament; exterior: from top, trace of brown band; key maeander frieze running left between bands; below, painted decoration consisting of goat grazing to right (head, antler, neck with added red blob, shoulder with red blob and one foreleg remaining); at right, possible tail of second goat; pendant roundel and triangle and spiked swastika as filling ornament.
Producer name: Attributed to: Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University College London. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The exterior surface of the sherd was burnt during the bombings in London in 1941 during WWII. According to Johnston, the sherd finds parallels with the Würzburg chalices (Lemos no. 236-7) although this sherd has more detail. Lemos attributes the sherd stylistically to the Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl. The sherd most probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.460.k, which Lemos took to be close to the Painter, not by him.
Bibliographic references: Johnston 1978 / Pottery from Naukratis: An Exhibition on the Occasion of the 11th International Congress of Classical Archaeology (no. 66)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 74, p. 243, no. 255, pl. 30)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2059) (phase 2)
